reviewText: Well done TV dramatic police movie. Thoughtful acting by Martin Sheen as a grief stricken detective in search of the Son Of Sam killer in NYC. A tribute to a good cop in a rough case, and it's Sheen's in depth character study that raised the bar in making things true and real. Watch for Joe Spinell a live wire suspect in the films best scenes. Fresh film making.

Recommended: This LION'S GATE dub has a sharp image with strong colors and Hi-Fi audio which gradually builds in volume after half the show is over. OUT OF THE DARKNESS was the first-ever film about NYC's Son of Sam murders, and yet it almost ISN'T, for the bulk of the story concerns NYC cop Ed Zigo's personal life. Note that the real Zigo cameos early on as a hostage negotiator. Also here in a prominent role is Eddie Egan, the cop who inspired THE FRENCH CONNECTION (1971). CAMEOS: Sheen's son Charlie, as a guy with shaving cream on his face, slams a front door on his dad. Papa remarks: "Nice boy." Eriq La Salle, of NBC-TV's ER, is seen briefly as "Bobby." Except for the last 20 minutes, "Sam" attacks are brief interruptions to the Zigo narrative. There's no graphic detail, obviously necessary for primetime TV. The general pattern: we see two kids in a car. Next is a sideview of a pistol firing to screen left, à la the "faster than a speeding bullet" title sequence from TV's THE ADVENTURES OF SUPERMAN. Safety glass shatters into miniscule cubes, the victims duck and that's it. Curiously, all of these episodes look alike. Once a key clue turns up, an otherwise innocuous parking ticket, there's a stakeout and arrest of David Berkowitz, but only after a lot of Zigo family drama goes by. SYNOPSIS After 24 years of service, Eddie Zigo's a Grade 2 detective. He'd like to retire as Grade 1, feels he's earned it, but there's a promotion freeze in effect. Further, his daughter's preparing to go off to college in a few months and wife Ann has fallen seriously ill. When a number of related nighttime shootings occur, anonymous letters from a professed killer calling himself "the Monster"and "Son of Sam" are sent to NYPD. With the enticement of a possible promotion to Det. 1st Grade, Zigo is asked to join a "Sam" task force. He's forced to choose between a career dream and caring for a seriously ill loved one. . Everything about this film feels authentic.  Police work is not glory and macho theatrics here.  It's daily drudge and trudge and the toll it takes on a hard-working officer's personal life can be enormous.  Sheen's character has a serious struggle with his religious faith also.  The best part of this movie is when he finally locates David Berkowitz and leads the capture.  Instead of getting tough, Det. Zigo and his fellow officers are all nervous and jumpy and don't want to make a mistake.
